OVERVIEW


 
It’s no secret that the Western United States is in dire need of new transmission capacity. 
 
With bourgeoning population centers growing throughout the West and new baseload generation, both fossil and renewable, being developed, delivering reliable electricity over the long-distance western landscape has become imperative. 
 
Yet, the western grid is unique in its expanse and its resource capabilities. Without an established RTO, planning for comprehensive transmission expansion becomes a combined effort by the states and the utilities that serve them. 
 
Many entities have taken initiative over the past few years and to date over 20 transmission projects are in some form of development. Yet for the most part, the Western US is building transmission capacity in advance of generation. 
 
How will this affect future projects and the long-term outlook on power purchasing from load serving entities?
While much of the planning and siting issues have been and continue to be addressed, issues still remain on the load mix and how states will meet air quality standards and RPS requirements.
  
How do utilities decide what type of power to buy, considering these constraints and what effect does that have on their interest in new transmission? 
 
For the numerous renewable energy projects in the West, how does building high capacity transmission encourage development and does it guarantee that renewable electricity will get to the places that need it and/or are required to have it?
 
 It seems there has been no shortage on the investment end for transmission expansion, yet there are staging issues that can delay the build-out. After initial interest is expressed in specific lines, what does financing look like at different stages for rights-of-way and EIS and then to actual construction? 
 
This conference will explore these issues in-depth with utilities, investment groups, regulators and other state officials.
